hey everybody welcome to my q com plus talk about the unreasonable effectiveness of zeroshot learning
my name is vladimir and i'm really excited about the opportunity to speak to you today
before we get started though i just want to reflect on the whole online conference experience
what i still love most about qcon is meeting new interesting people discussing challenges in your work in
artificial intelligence in robotics etc and answering questions you might have
about this talk or about anything ai related so i'm currently in chat i can answer
any question you have and i hope to see you in the hallway track later
now let's get started by talking about machine learning projects in general in my career i often went through the
following phases when setting up a machine learning project i would
i would often first determine the requirements of what my program or neural network has to do i would then go
out and collect and label data and then i would straight machine learning model and only then would i deploy my bottle
and get feedback from my boss other teams clients etc so
unfortunately i noticed that the first time i would define my requirements i would often miss things get things wrong
requirements would change if you're working a startup quite often um and the collecting and labeling data
step is very expensive and takes a long time so before you get any feedback and before
your requirements are probably going to change it takes you a long time and that's a really expensive project
process so recently i found a way to radically speed up machine learning project
development using a technique called zero shot learning and right now you might be wondering hey
roland who are you actually what is your stake in getting us to annotate less data well i'm a product manager at anato
which is a data annotation and at least company for self-talking cars so although it might sound pretty ironic
that someone who has a stake in data annotation is going to tell you about doing less data annotation
i think it's important to make sure that people have a a good understanding of what kind of
problem they're trying to solve before they actually go at it and that way they can build the high quality data sets
which are necessary especially for self-writing car projects so if we go back to the problem at hand
i think the big underlying question for this talk is can we start by determining requirements
and deploying our application at the same time wouldn't that be dreamy wouldn't it be fantastic if we could do
that so to assess this question i basically thought of two projects to try to do during this
talk which uh might benefit from something like zero shot learning
so the first idea i had was let's say that we have a startup
lyriclicious or something and we want to determine the language a lyric is written or song is written in
so let's say that you have the lyric i'm in love with the shape of you that's english allo and dance that would of
course be a french song no nonsense blunt would be a german song so yeah we basically have a media
function which gets some texas input and um gets the language as output
the second example i thought of for our um for this talk was
let's speed up self-checkout fruit scanning so if you are going to a supermarket you know you
often have to weigh products yourself and you have to indicate what kind of fruit or veggie
board is it always takes me a long time to find them and so that's why i went to the supermarket bought some fruits and
vegetables and let's try to build a scanning application which can recognize these fruit and vegetables
and it actually took me a bit of time to do this because when i was buying it the person behind the desk couldn't find the
code for a carrot so i thought that made the problem extra relevant
so yeah maybe right now take a bit of a moment to
think about how you would approach these problems normally what kind of data would you collect
how much time would that take an example especially if in the case of these
examples if you were really working on startup uh what kind of changes and requirements can you expect in the future

so how would that oh and maybe what kind of collisions would you see between the different uh fruits and

and while you do that i will talk about so-called foundational models
so foundational models are models which are trained on a broad scale of data and
can be adapted to a wide range of downstream tasks
last year stanford founded the center for research on foundational models i think actually might have even done it
this year and these models are too big to train for yourself or by
yourself so you have to download a pre-trained model or use an api
or yeah it's basically a you you just download the model and you kind
of maybe treat it as a black box especially during this talk we will do that um but you yeah the new research view is
kind of trying to see what can we do with these models how can we use them and you might already know a couple of
these models so one example is tp3 which can finish your natural language query
open ai codecs can finish your code if you are having invites to
github copilots and there's open eye clip which operates on images and text
yeah so let's start with the first model we're going to look at today
gt3 which is a generative pre-trained transformer is basically an autocomplete algorithm
so if you give it a sequence of tokens or sequence of letters or sequence of text
it will try to predict the next token or the next text
it is pre-trained in a generative unsupervised manner on 570 gigabytes of internet data
so what open ai did is they just scraped the internet for web pages books wikipedia i think wikipedia wrote text
is only 10 gigabytes so the model has seen a lot of text
has seen a lot of things um yeah and it's also a massive model with 175
billion parameters so it won't even fit on your gpu anymore so it can only be used through the openai api
and just to give you an example of how this what is autocompletion is i think it's
common if you're learning machine learning that people try to teach you some lcms
and they let you make some shakespeare generate or something so you could have a text like what doesn't kill
us makes us and then if you send that to the openi api it could either return something
like anger or aggro or i've which are all nice ways to finish this
sentence what doesn't give us makes us stronger or stronger or strive
so some examples of generative text which you could generate with the open eye api
or with any autocomplete algorithm at all it would be the quick brown fox jumps over lazy dog
or shall i compare v to a it could be summer's day if you're a shakespeare fan but it could
also be anything else like short compared to a nice spring evening i don't know all
kinds of things are possible and so what uh what people are also doing with these autocomplete algorithms
are for example they're giving it the text how are you doing answer
and that way gp3 can autocomplete it with i am fine and this is the way that people talk to these algorithms um they try to
see how gpt3 is feeling by just seeing how to complete sentences like this
you can write poetry like if you have a bow if you just input it poem name
shadows on the way um then it's possible for gt3 to generate something like i must have
shadows on the way if i am to walk i must have each step taken slowly and alone to have it ready made
so yeah beautiful poetry it can be generated with these kind of autocomplete algorithms
but now we get to some more interesting examples so let's say that you say the capital of france is
and then you let that out like this api outcompleted there's hopefully a high chance that it
says paris because it's read this text on the internet or has seen similar texts
and if you say 20 plus 22 is hopefully it will autocomplete as 42
because it has just learned this or seen texts like this
um and that kind of brings me to the point of gpt3
it's not just an interesting thing to play with you can actually try to use it as a
generic everything in and out api with of course the asterix that are no

complete this text task for which general knowledge is required
can be given to gp3 and in my experience it kind of can take
everything which like a board high schooler would do unlike a test um
like it would auto complete some things in a roughly reasonable fashion
but of course it's not perfect kind of looks looks like lazy looks a bit sloppy um

and if you for example on the right have this is a program which improves english grammar poor english output i eat it the

one example of a text which has to autocomplete and then it
it has to complete next things so if we go back to our solving our

layers are written in lyric and then you give the lyric and then language and then it has to autocomplete this
language so i wrote this simple function i use the openai api
and as you can see it's really a small function if you use the api but yeah if you give the text i'm in love with the

this python function which returns a correct answer um yeah i think this is brilliant and this
really can speed up our product development if we had this as a product so i want to give you some pro tips
because i've been playing around with this for a long time over the last spring in case you only have a few answer
options like in this case we might only say oh we have english french or german
it makes sense to tell that you do gt3 in the first line so you can say there's a program which determines if text is
english french or german so it doesn't necessarily repeat things it saw in the text before but it does
seem to prime these words to come up more quickly and the second tip is that language
models are few shot learners so that's the title of the paper
opening i used to announce gp3 to reward but it basically means that if you
give it some examples the autocompletion will work better
um so it's a good primer for your query so try to use each of the possible use cases or maybe try to use each of the
languages before you give it a new language and then hopefully latch to that
and the last step which i frequently do is i allow the api to return multiple options
or like multiple autocomplete options like with what doesn't give us makes us
like i just let it return three things and then you can use a heuristic to select the best option like you can
have something return i don't know three three answers for what um
text the what language a song text is in and then i just because i know it's
either french english or german i would just see if it returned any of these things and then i use that
so yeah that's it for gt3 you can sign up on the opening i website for the beta
and hopefully get access if you have a good idea and that brings me to my second task
which we wanted to tackle during this talk is zero shot image classification but openi also has something for that
they have open eye clip which stands for contrastive language image pre-training
and so what this model does is that it brings together text and image embeddings
so it generates an embedding for each text and it generates an
embedding for each image and these inputs are aligned to each other
so the way this model is trained is that for example you have a set of images
like an image of a cute puppy and then you have a set of texts like a
pepperoni pop and the way it's trained is that hopefully the distance between the
picture of this puppy and the or the sorry the embedding of this picture of this puppy
and the embedding of the text pepperdine pub that that is really close to each other
um and it's trained on 400 million image
text pairs which were scraped from the internet so if you you you can imagine that someone
did indeed put an image of a puppy on the internet and did right under it this
is speculative and the brilliant thing is that because
we have an embedding for text and we have an embedding for images and these are aligned to each other
we can use this for zero shot prediction of images so if you have a picture of a
puppy you can have and you know that it's either a plane or
a car or a dog or bird you can just get the embedding for a photo of a playing
card dog and birds and then see which of the embeddings of these
texts is closest to the embedding of the image
and hopefully that would be the a photo of a doc query so now let's go back to our solving our
scanning application using geoshock learning so what we can do is we can gather embedding for each of the labels
we have like the carrot potato a bunch of grapes and an empty table in this case if we want
